From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

National Football League franchise in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

"Steelers" redirects here. For other uses, see [Steelers (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steelers_(disambiguation) "Steelers (disambiguation)").

‹ The [template](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Template "Help:Template") _[Infobox NFL team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Infobox_NFL_team "Template:Infobox NFL team")_ is being [considered for merging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Templates_for_discussion/Log/2025_October_1#Gridiron_football_team_templates "Wikipedia:Templates for discussion/Log/2025 October 1"). ›

| Pittsburgh Steelers |

The **Pittsburgh Steelers** are a professional [American football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_football "American football") team based in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"). The Steelers compete in the [National Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") (NFL) as a member of the [American Football Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football Conference") (AFC) [North](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_North "AFC North") division. Founded in [1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1933_Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NFL)_season "1933 Pittsburgh Pirates (NFL) season"), the Steelers are the seventh-oldest franchise in the NFL, and the oldest franchise in the AFC.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7)

In contrast with their status as a perennial losing franchise in the pre- [merger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFL%E2%80%93NFL_merger "AFL–NFL merger") NFL, where they were the oldest team never to have won a league championship, the Steelers of the post- [merger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFL%E2%80%93NFL_merger "AFL–NFL merger") (modern) era are among the most successful NFL franchises, especially during their dynasty in the 1970s.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-i929-8)[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-u452-9)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-f575-10) The team is tied with the [New England Patriots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") for the most [Super Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") titles at six, and they have both played in (16 times) and hosted (11 times) more conference championship games than any other team in the NFL. The Steelers have also won eight [AFC championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game"), tied with the [Denver Broncos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos"), but behind the Patriots' record 11 AFC championships. The team is tied with the Broncos, [Dallas Cowboys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"), and [San Francisco 49ers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") for the second-most Super Bowl appearances with eight.

The Steelers, whose history may be traced to a [regional pro team that was established in the early 1920s](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J.P._Rooneys "J.P. Rooneys"), joined the NFL as the **Pittsburgh Pirates** on July 8, 1933. The team was owned by [Art Rooney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Rooney "Art Rooney") and took its original name from the [baseball team of the same name](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates "Pittsburgh Pirates"), as was common practice for NFL teams at the time.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7) To distinguish them from the baseball team, local media took to calling the football team the **Rooneymen**, an unofficial nickname that persisted for decades after the team had adopted its current nickname. The ownership of the Steelers has remained within the Rooney family since the organization's founding.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-11) Art Rooney's son, [Dan Rooney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Rooney "Dan Rooney"), owned the team from 1988 until his death in 2017. Much control of the franchise has been given to Dan Rooney's son, [Art Rooney II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Rooney_II "Art Rooney II").

The Steelers enjoy a large, widespread [fanbase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#Fanbase) nicknamed [Steeler Nation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steeler_Nation "Steeler Nation").[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-Mosley-12) They currently play their home games at [Acrisure Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acrisure_Stadium "Acrisure Stadium") on Pittsburgh's [North Side](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Side_(Pittsburgh) "North Side (Pittsburgh)") in the [North Shore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Shore_(Pittsburgh) "North Shore (Pittsburgh)") neighborhood, which also hosts the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh") [Panthers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_football "Pittsburgh Panthers football"). Built in 2001 as Heinz Field, the stadium replaced [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium"), which had hosted the Steelers for 31 seasons. Prior to Three Rivers, the Steelers had played their games in [Pitt Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitt_Stadium "Pitt Stadium") and at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field").

## History

Further information: [History of the Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Pittsburgh_Steelers "History of the Pittsburgh Steelers")

See also: [American football in Western Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_football_in_Western_Pennsylvania "American football in Western Pennsylvania")

### Rooney family era (1933–present)

The Steelers first took to the field as the [Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1933_Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NFL)_season "1933 Pittsburgh Pirates (NFL) season") on September 20, 1933, losing 23–2 to the [New York Giants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1933_New_York_Giants_season "1933 New York Giants season").[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7) Through the 1930s, the Pirates never finished higher than second place in their division, or with a record better than .500 ( [1936](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1936_Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NFL)_season "1936 Pittsburgh Pirates (NFL) season")).[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-13) Pittsburgh did make history in [1938](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1938_Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NFL)_season "1938 Pittsburgh Pirates (NFL) season") by signing [Byron White](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byron_White "Byron White"), a future [Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States") of the [U.S. Supreme Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court "U.S. Supreme Court"), to what was at the time the biggest contract in NFL history, but he played only one year with the Pirates before signing with the [Detroit Lions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Lions "Detroit Lions").[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7)[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-14) Prior to the 1940 season, the Pirates renamed themselves the Steelers.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-g876-15)

During World War II, the Steelers experienced player shortages. They twice merged with other NFL franchises to field a team. During the [1943 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1943_NFL_season "1943 NFL season"), they merged with the [Philadelphia Eagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") forming the "Phil-Pitt Eagles" and were known as the " [Steagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steagles "Steagles")". This team went 5–4–1.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-16) In [1944](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1944_NFL_season "1944 NFL season"), they merged with the [Chicago Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Cardinals_(NFL,_1920%E2%80%9359) "Chicago Cardinals (NFL, 1920–59)") and were known as Card-Pitt (or, mockingly, as the "Carpets").[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7) This team finished 0–10, marking the only winless team in franchise history.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-17)

The [Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1947_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1947 Pittsburgh Steelers season") made the playoffs for the first time in [1947](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1947_NFL_season "1947 NFL season"), tying for first place in the division at 8–4 with the [Philadelphia Eagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1947_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1947 Philadelphia Eagles season"). This forced a [tie-breaking playoff game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1947_NFL_playoffs "1947 NFL playoffs") at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field"), which the Steelers lost 21–0.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-18) That would be Pittsburgh's only playoff game in the pre-merger era; they did qualify for a " [Playoff Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Playoff_Bowl "Playoff Bowl")" in 1962 as the second-best team in their conference, but this was not considered an official playoff.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-19)

In [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1970 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), the year they moved into [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") and the year of the [AFL–NFL merger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFL%E2%80%93NFL_merger "AFL–NFL merger"), the Pittsburgh Steelers were one of three old-guard NFL teams to switch to the newly formed [American Football Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football Conference") (the others being the [Cleveland Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") and the [Baltimore Colts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_Colts "Baltimore Colts")), in order to equalize the number of teams in the two conferences of the newly merged league.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-o274-20) The Steelers also received a $3 million ($24.3 million today) relocation fee, which was a windfall for them; for years they rarely had enough to build a true contending team.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-21)

#### Chuck Noll years (1969–1991)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/1983_Steelers_Police_-_04_Terry_Bradshaw_%28crop%29.jpg/175px-1983_Steelers_Police_-_04_Terry_Bradshaw_%28crop%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1983_Steelers_Police_-_04_Terry_Bradshaw_(crop).jpg) [Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame") quarterback [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw") led the Steelers to four Super Bowl titles during the 1970s.

The Steelers' history of bad luck changed with the hiring of coach [Chuck Noll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Noll "Chuck Noll") from the NFL champion Baltimore Colts for the [1969 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1969_NFL_season "1969 NFL season").[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-22) Noll's most remarkable talent was in his draft selections, taking Hall of Famers ["Mean" Joe Greene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Greene "Joe Greene") in [1969](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1969_NFL_draft "1969 NFL draft"), [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw") and [Mel Blount](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_Blount "Mel Blount") in [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_NFL_draft "1970 NFL draft"), [Jack Ham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Ham "Jack Ham") in [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_NFL_draft "1971 NFL draft"), [Franco Harris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Harris "Franco Harris") in [1972](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1972_NFL_draft "1972 NFL draft"),[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-23) and finally, in 1974, pulling off the incredible feat of selecting four Hall of Famers in one draft year, [Lynn Swann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynn_Swann "Lynn Swann"), [Jack Lambert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Lambert_(American_football) "Jack Lambert (American football)"), [John Stallworth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Stallworth "John Stallworth"), and [Mike Webster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Webster "Mike Webster").[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-n514-24) The Pittsburgh Steelers' [1974 draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1974_NFL_draft "1974 NFL draft") was their best ever; no other team has ever drafted four future Hall of Famers in one year, and only very few (including the 1970 Steelers) have drafted two or more in one year.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-r189-25)

The players drafted in the early 1970s formed the base of an NFL dynasty, making the playoffs in eight seasons and becoming the only team in NFL history to win four [Super Bowls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") in six years, as well as the first to win more than two.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-26) They also enjoyed a regular-season streak of 49 consecutive wins ( [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1971 Pittsburgh Steelers season")– [1979](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1979 Pittsburgh Steelers season")) against teams that would finish with a losing record that year.

The [Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1980 Pittsburgh Steelers season") suffered a rash of injuries in the [1980 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1980_NFL_season "1980 NFL season") and missed the playoffs with a 9–7 record.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-27) The [1981 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1981_NFL_season "1981 NFL season") was no better, with an 8–8 showing.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-28) The team was then hit with the retirements of all their key players from the Super Bowl years. "Mean" Joe Greene retired after the [1981 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1981_NFL_season "1981 NFL season"), Lynn Swann and Jack Ham after [1982](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1982_NFL_season "1982 NFL season")'s playoff berth, Terry Bradshaw and Mel Blount after [1983](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_NFL_season "1983 NFL season")'s divisional championship, and Jack Lambert after [1984](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1984_NFL_season "1984 NFL season")'s AFC Championship Game appearance.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-29)

After those retirements, the franchise skidded to its first losing seasons since 1971. Though still competitive, the Steelers would not finish above .500 in [1985](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1985_NFL_season "1985 NFL season"), [1986](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1986_NFL_season "1986 NFL season"), and [1988](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_NFL_season "1988 NFL season"). In [1987](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987_NFL_season "1987 NFL season"), the year of the [players' strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987_NFL_strike "1987 NFL strike"), the [Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1987 Pittsburgh Steelers season") finished with a record of 8–7, but missed the playoffs.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-30) In [1989](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1989_NFL_season "1989 NFL season"), they would reach the second round of the playoffs on the strength of [Merrill Hoge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merrill_Hoge "Merrill Hoge") and [Rod Woodson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Woodson "Rod Woodson") before narrowly missing the playoffs in each of the next two seasons, Noll's last seasons.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-v031-31)

Noll's career record with Pittsburgh was 209–156–1.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-32)

#### Bill Cowher years (1992–2006)

In 1992, [Chuck Noll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Noll "Chuck Noll") retired and was succeeded by [Kansas City Chiefs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs "Kansas City Chiefs") defensive coordinator [Bill Cowher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Cowher "Bill Cowher"), a native of the Pittsburgh suburb of [Crafton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crafton,_Pennsylvania "Crafton, Pennsylvania").[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-33)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Pittsburgh_Steelers_five_rings.jpg/250px-Pittsburgh_Steelers_five_rings.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Steelers_five_rings.jpg) Steelers' five Super Bowl rings before 2009

Cowher led the Steelers to the playoffs in each of his first six seasons, a feat that had been accomplished only by legendary coach [Paul Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Brown "Paul Brown") of the [Cleveland Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns"). In those first six seasons, Cowher coached them as deep as the [AFC Championship Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game") three times and following the [1995 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_NFL_season "1995 NFL season") an appearance in [Super Bowl XXX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXX "Super Bowl XXX") on the strength of the "Blitzburgh" defense. However, the Steelers lost to the [Dallas Cowboys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_Dallas_Cowboys_season "1995 Dallas Cowboys season") in Super Bowl XXX, two weeks after a thrilling [AFC Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_AFC_Championship_game "1995 AFC Championship game") victory over the [Indianapolis Colts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_Indianapolis_Colts_season "1995 Indianapolis Colts season").[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-34)[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-35) Cowher produced the franchise's record-tying fifth Super Bowl win in [Super Bowl XL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XL "Super Bowl XL") over the [NFC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_Conference "National Football Conference") champion [Seattle Seahawks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Seattle_Seahawks_season "2005 Seattle Seahawks season") ten years later.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-j391-36) With that victory, the Steelers became the third team to win five Super Bowls, and the first sixth-seeded playoff team to reach and win the Super Bowl since the NFL expanded to a 12-team post-season tournament in 1990. He coached through the 2006 season which ended with an 8–8 record, just short of the playoffs. Overall Cowher's teams reached the playoffs 10 of 15 seasons with six AFC Championship Games, two Super Bowl berths and a championship.

Cowher's career record with Pittsburgh was 149–90–1 in the regular season and 161–99–1 overall, including playoff games.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-37)

#### Mike Tomlin years (2007–present)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Ben_Roethlisberger_throwback.jpg/250px-Ben_Roethlisberger_throwback.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ben_Roethlisberger_throwback.jpg) Roethlisberger in a Steelers' throwback jersey during the team's 500th win in franchise history

On January 7, 2007, Cowher resigned from coaching the Steelers, citing a need to spend more time with his family. He did not use the term "retire", leaving open a possible return to the NFL as coach of another team.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-g896-38) A three-man committee consisting of Art Rooney II, Dan Rooney, and Kevin Colbert was set up to conduct interviews for the head coaching vacancy.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-39) On January 22, 2007, [Minnesota Vikings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings") defensive coordinator [Mike Tomlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Tomlin "Mike Tomlin") was announced as Cowher's successor as head coach.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-40) Tomlin is the first African-American to be named head coach of the team in its 75-year history.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-i182-41) In his first season, he led the Steelers to a 10–6 record and AFC North title.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-l037-42) The team fell to the Jacksonville Jaguars 31–29 in the Wild Card Round to end the season.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-n527-43) The following year, he led the Steelers to a 12–4 mark and a division title.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-z592-44) With wins over the San Diego Chargers in the Divisional Round and the Baltimore Ravens in the AFC Championship,[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-45)[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-46) Tomlin became the third consecutive Steelers Head Coach to go to the Super Bowl, equaling the Dallas Cowboys (Tom Landry, Jimmy Johnson and Barry Switzer) in this achievement. On February 1, 2009, Tomlin led the Steelers to their second Super Bowl of this decade, and went on to win 27–23 against the [Arizona Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2008 Arizona Cardinals season").[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-47) At age 36, he was the youngest head coach to ever win the Super Bowl, and he is only the second African-American coach to ever win the Super Bowl ( [Tony Dungy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Dungy "Tony Dungy") was the first).[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-w891-48) In their title defense, the Steelers went 9–7 and missed the postseason in the 2009 season.[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-t523-49) In the 2010 season, Tomlin led the team to a 12–4 record and an AFC North title.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-j132-50) The team defeated the Baltimore Ravens in the Divisional Round and the New York Jets in the AFC Championship.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-51)[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-52) Tomlin became the only coach to reach the Super Bowl twice before the age of 40 as he took the team to [Super Bowl XLV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV") on February 6, 2011. However, the Steelers were defeated by the [Green Bay Packers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers"), 31–25.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-53)

In the 2011 season, the Steelers made the postseason with a 12–4 record. They lost in overtime to the Denver Broncos in the Wild Card Round.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-a254-54) The Steelers recorded their 400th victory in Week 8 of the 2012 season after defeating the [Washington Redskins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins").[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-55) Overall, the Steelers went 8–8 and missed the postseason in 2012.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-56) In the 2013 season, the Steelers went 8–8 and missed the postseason.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-57) In the 2014 season, the Steelers won the AFC North with a 11–5 record.[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-58) They lost 30–17 to the Baltimore Ravens in the Wild Card Round.[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-l295-59) The Steelers finished with a 10–6 record and made the playoffs in the 2015 season.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-60) They defeated the Cincinnati Bengals in the Wild Card Round and lost to the Denver Broncos in the Divisional Round.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-ChrisBurke-61)[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-j441-62) In the 2016 season, the Steelers won the AFC North with a 11–5 record.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-63) They defeated the Miami Dolphins in the Wild Card Round and the Kansas City Chiefs in the Divisional Round before falling to the New England Patriots in the AFC Championship.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-64)[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-65)[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-c488-66) In the 2017 season, the Steelers won the AFC North with a 13–3 mark.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-67) Their postseason was short lived with a 45–42 loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars.[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-h977-68) Despite a 9–6–1 record in the 2018 season, the Steelers missed the playoffs.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-69) The Steelers went 8–8 and missed the postseason in the 2019 season.[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-70) The 2020 season saw the Steelers have franchise-best 11–0 start.[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-t291-71) However, the team faded at the end of the season to finish 12–4.[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-72) The team lost in the Wild Card Round to the Cleveland Browns 48–37.[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-a671-73) The 2021 season saw the team go 9–7–1 and make the postseason.[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-74) The Steelers lost 42–21 to the Kansas City Chiefs in the Wild Card Round.[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-w218-75) Longtime quarterback Ben Roethlisberger retired following the 2021 season.[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-q084-76)

Through the end of the 2021 season, Tomlin's record is 162–94–2 (.632), including playoffs. He is the first Pittsburgh coach to never post a losing season. The 2013–17 seasons were noted for record performances from the " [Killer B's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Killer_B%27s_(Pittsburgh) "Killer B's (Pittsburgh)")". This trio consisted of [Antonio Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Brown "Antonio Brown"), [Ben Roethlisberger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Roethlisberger "Ben Roethlisberger") and [Le'Veon Bell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%27Veon_Bell "Le'Veon Bell").[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-l395-77) Occasionally, the "Killer B's" has also included kicker [Chris Boswell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Boswell "Chris Boswell") due to his ability to hit game-winning field goals.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-m568-78)

Prior to the 2022 season, the team drafted Pitt quarterback Kenny Pickett with their first round pick in the 2022 NFL draft.[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-l434-79) Pickett started 12 games as the Steelers went 9–8 and missed the postseason in the 2022 season.[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-80) In the 2023 season, the team finished 10–7 and third in the AFC North.[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-81) They made the playoffs and were defeated by the Buffalo Bills in the Wild Card Round 31–17.[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-82) Prior to the 2024 season, the Steelers traded Pickett to the Philadelphia Eagles.[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-x583-83) The team traded for Justin Fields from the Chicago Bears and signed Russell Wilson, who was released from the Denver Broncos.[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-t170-84)[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-c260-85)

### Summary

Since the NFL merger in 1970, the Pittsburgh Steelers have compiled a regular-season record of 444–282–2 (.635) and an overall record of 480–305–2 (.635) including the playoffs, reached the playoffs 30 times, won their division 22 times, played in 16 AFC championship games, and won six of eight Super Bowls. They are also the only NFL team not to have a season with 12 or more losses since the league expanded to a 16-game schedule in 1978.[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-86)

### Ownership

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/ArtRooneyII_closeup.jpg/250px-ArtRooneyII_closeup.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ArtRooneyII_closeup.jpg) [Art Rooney II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Rooney_II "Art Rooney II"), controlling owner of the Steelers

Since 2008, the [Rooney family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rooney_family "Rooney family") has brought in several investors for the team while retaining control of the team itself. This came about so that the team could comply with NFL ownership regulations.[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-87) [Dan Rooney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Rooney "Dan Rooney"), and his son, [Art Rooney II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Rooney_II "Art Rooney II"), president of the franchise, wanted to stay involved with the franchise, while two of the brothers – Timothy and Patrick – wanted to further pursue [racetracks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing") that they own in Florida and New York.[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-88) Since 2006, many of the racetracks have added [video slot machines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slot_machine "Slot machine"), causing them to violate "NFL policy that prohibits involvement with racetrack and gambling interests".[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-89)

- Several other members of the Rooney family, including [Art Rooney Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Rooney_Jr. "Art Rooney Jr."), John Rooney, and the McGinley family, who are cousins to the Rooneys.
- The Robert A. Paul family of Pittsburgh and Los Angeles, which is primarily involved with Pittsburgh-based [Ampco Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ampco_Pittsburgh "Ampco Pittsburgh") Corporation as well as Morton's Restaurant Group, Urban Active Fitness, Meyer Products and Harley Marine Services. Additionally, family members serve on numerous [boards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Board_of_directors "Board of directors"), including Cornell University, [UPMC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_Medical_Center "University of Pittsburgh Medical Center"), [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"), the [American Red Cross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Red_Cross "American Red Cross"), [Harvard Medical School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_Medical_School "Harvard Medical School") and the [Loomis Chaffee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loomis_Chaffee "Loomis Chaffee") School.[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-Haslam-90)

Rauner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Rauner "Bruce Rauner").[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-Stallworth-91)[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Pittsburgh_Steelers_at_the_White_House_2009-05-21_2.JPG/250px-Pittsburgh_Steelers_at_the_White_House_2009-05-21_2.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Steelers_at_the_White_House_2009-05-21_2.JPG) President Obama poses with the Steelers in 2009. ### Season-by-season records

Further information: [List of Pittsburgh Steelers seasons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_Steelers_seasons "List of Pittsburgh Steelers seasons")

Through the end of the [2023 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2023 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), the Steelers have an all-time record of 707–606–22, including playoffs. In recent seasons the Steelers have generally performed well, qualifying for the playoffs six times in the past ten seasons, while winning their division four times.[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-FranchiseEncyclopedia-95)

In the NFL's "modern era" (since the AFL–NFL merger in 1970) the Steelers have posted the best record in the league. The franchise has won the most regular-season games, the most playoff games (33 playoff wins; the Dallas Cowboys are second with 32), won the most divisional titles (20), has played in the most conference championship games (15), hosted the most conference championship games (11), and is tied with the Dallas Cowboys, the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots for the most Super Bowl appearances (8).[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-x423-96) The Steelers have the best winning percentage (including every expansion team), earned the most All-Pro nominations, and have accumulated the most Super Bowl wins (6) since the modern game started in 1970. In 2017, they became the first team to reach 450 victories in the regular season since the 1970 merger.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-450Wins-97)[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-98) The Steelers are 36–26 (.580) in the postseason, with all but one (the 1947 playoff) having been played since the merger.[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-99)

### Civil rights advocacy

The franchise, along with the Rooney family have for generations been strong advocates for equality of opportunity for both minorities and women. Among these achievements of the Steelers was the first to hire an African-American assistant coach (September 29, 1957, with [Lowell Perry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lowell_Perry "Lowell Perry")), the first to start an African-American quarterback (December 3, 1973, with [Joe Gilliam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Gilliam "Joe Gilliam")),[\[a\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-100) the first team to boast of an African-American Super Bowl MVP (January 12, 1975, with [Franco Harris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Harris "Franco Harris")), the first to hire an African-American Coordinator (September 2, 1984, with [Tony Dungy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Dungy "Tony Dungy")), the first owner to push for passage of an "equal opportunity" mandating that at least one minority candidate is given an interview in all head coach hiring decisions throughout the league (the Rooney Rule in the early 2000s), and the first to hire a female as full-time athletic trainer ( [Ariko Iso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariko_Iso "Ariko Iso") on July 24, 2002).[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-d636-101)
