### Division championships

The Steelers were a part of the NFL Eastern Division from 1933 to 1943 and were briefly in the Western Division in 1944, before returning to the Eastern Division until 1949. The team was then in the American Conference from 1950 to 1952, and the Eastern Conference from 1953 to 1966. They were then placed in the Century Division of the Eastern Conference in 1967. When the league reformed into the NFC and AFC in 1970, the Steelers were placed in the AFC Central until 2001 when they were realigned into the AFC North Division.

## Logo and uniforms

Further information: [Logos and uniforms of the Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logos_and_uniforms_of_the_Pittsburgh_Steelers "Logos and uniforms of the Pittsburgh Steelers")

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/US_Airways_Steelers.jpg/250px-US_Airways_Steelers.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:US_Airways_Steelers.jpg) A US Airways A319 featuring the colors and logo of the Pittsburgh Steelers. This Airbus A319 has since been repainted into American Airlines colors after [the merger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Airways-American_Airlines_merger "US Airways-American Airlines merger").

The Steelers have used black and gold as their colors since the club's inception, the lone exception being the 1943 season when they merged with the [Philadelphia Eagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") and formed the " [Steagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steagles "Steagles")"; the team's colors at that time were green and white as a result of wearing Eagles uniforms. Originally, the team wore solid gold-colored helmets and black jerseys. The Steelers' black and gold colors are now shared by all major professional teams in the city, including the [Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates "Pittsburgh Pirates") in baseball and the [Pittsburgh Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins") in ice hockey. The shade of gold differs slightly among teams: the Penguins have previously used "Vegas Gold", a color similar to metallic gold, and the Pirates' gold is a darker mustard yellow-gold, while the Steelers "gold" is more of a bright canary yellow. Black and gold are also the colors of the [city's official flag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania "Flag of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania").

The Steelers logo was introduced in 1962 and is based on the " [Steelmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steelmark "Steelmark")", originally designed by Pittsburgh's [U.S. Steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Steel "U.S. Steel") and now owned by the [American Iron and Steel Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Iron_and_Steel_Institute "American Iron and Steel Institute") (AISI). In fact, it was [Cleveland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland")-based [Republic Steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_Steel "Republic Steel") that suggested the Steelers adopt the industry logo. It consists of the word "Steelers" surrounded by three [astroids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astroid "Astroid") ( [hypocycloids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypocycloid "Hypocycloid") of four [cusps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cusp_(singularity) "Cusp (singularity)")). The original meanings behind the astroids were, "Steel lightens your work, brightens your leisure, and widens your world." Later, the colors came to represent the ingredients used in the steel-making process: yellow for coal, red for iron ore, and blue for scrap steel.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-102) While the formal Steelmark logo contains only the word "Steel", the team was given permission to add "ers" in 1963 after a petition to AISI.

The Steelers are the only NFL team that puts its logo on only one side of the helmet (the right side). Longtime field and equipment manager Jack Hart was instructed to do this by Art Rooney as a test to see how the logo appeared on the gold helmets; however, its popularity led the team to leave it that way permanently.[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-103) A year after introducing the logo, they switched to black helmets to make it stand out more.

The Steelers, along with the [New York Giants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants"), are one of only two teams in the [National Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") to have the players' uniform numbers on both the front and back of the helmets.

The current uniform designs were introduced in [1968](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1968 Pittsburgh Steelers season"). The design consists of gold pants and either black jerseys or white jerseys, except for the [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1970 Pittsburgh Steelers season") and [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1971 Pittsburgh Steelers season") seasons when the Steelers wore white pants with their white jerseys. In [1997](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1997 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), the team switched to rounded numbers on the jersey to match the number font ( [Futura Condensed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Futura_Condensed "Futura Condensed")) on the helmets, and a Steelers logo was added to the left side of the jersey.

The 2007–2011 third uniform, consisting of a black jersey with gold lettering, white pants with black and gold stripes, and a gold helmet were first used during the Steelers' 75th anniversary season in [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2007 Pittsburgh Steelers season"). They were meant to evoke the memory of the [1963](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1963_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1963 Pittsburgh Steelers season")– [1964](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1964 Pittsburgh Steelers season") era uniforms. The uniforms were so popular among fans that the Steelers' organization decided to keep them and use them as a third option during home games only.

In 2012, the Steelers introduced a new third uniform, consisting of a yellow jersey with black horizontal lines (making a bumble bee like pattern) with black lettering and black numbers placed inside a white box, to represent the jerseys worn by the Steelers in their [1934 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1934_Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NFL)_season "1934 Pittsburgh Pirates (NFL) season"). The rest of the uniform consists of beige pants, yellow with black horizontal striped socks, and the Steelers regular black helmet. The uniforms were used for the Steelers' 80th anniversary season. Much like the previous alternate these jerseys were so popular that they were used up through the 2016 season. The jerseys were nicknamed the "bumblebee jerseys" due to looking like the pattern of a bumblebee. The jerseys were retired after the 2016 season.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-a901-104)

Also in 2016, the Steelers introduced its alternate black _[Color Rush](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Color_Rush "NFL Color Rush")_ uniforms. These were based on the uniforms they wore from 1946 to 1965, but with black pants in place of either gold or white pants.

In 2018, the Steelers unveiled a third uniform based on those worn from 1968 to 1997, coinciding with the Steel Curtain teams of the 1970s. It is similar to the current uniforms but without the Steelers logo on the left chest and use block lettering and numbers in place of Futura Condensed.[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-105)

In 1979, the team owners were approached by then- [Iowa Hawkeyes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iowa_Hawkeyes_football "Iowa Hawkeyes football") Head Coach [Hayden Fry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hayden_Fry "Hayden Fry") about designing his fading college team's uniforms in the image of the Steelers.[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-b813-106) Three days later, the owners sent Fry the reproduction jerseys (home and away versions) of then quarterback [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw"). Today, the Hawkeyes still retain the 1979 Steelers uniforms as their home, and away colors.

## Rivals

The Pittsburgh Steelers have three primary rivals, all within their division: ( [Cleveland Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns"), [Baltimore Ravens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens"), and [Cincinnati Bengals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals "Cincinnati Bengals")). They also have rivalries with other teams that arose from post-season battles in the past, most notably the [Las Vegas Raiders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas_Raiders "Las Vegas Raiders"), [Dallas Cowboys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"), [Denver Broncos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos"), [New England Patriots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots"), and [Tennessee Titans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans"). They also have an intrastate [rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Eagles–Steelers rivalry") with the [Philadelphia Eagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles"), but under the current scheduling the teams play each other only once every four years.[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-107)[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-108)[\[108\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-109)

### Divisional rivals

#### Cleveland Browns

Main article: [Browns–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Browns%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Browns–Steelers rivalry")

The Steelers and [Cleveland Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") have been divisional rivals since the two cities' teams began playing against each other in 1950. After posting a 9–31 record in the first 40 games of the series between the two cities, the Steelers have gone 66–27–1 (including 42–6 in games played in Pittsburgh) since 1970 and currently lead the series 75–58–1;[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-110) The Steelers have particularly dominated the Browns since their return to the NFL in 1999 and won twelve straight meetings between 2003 and 2009. Additionally, the Browns posted losing streaks of 16 (1970–85) and 15 (2004–present) games in Pittsburgh. Former Steelers head coach [Bill Cowher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Cowher "Bill Cowher") coached the Browns special teams and secondary before following [Marty Schottenheimer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marty_Schottenheimer "Marty Schottenheimer") for a brief tenure as [Kansas City Chiefs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs "Kansas City Chiefs") defensive coordinator and then hired by Pittsburgh. This has only intensified the rivalry. The teams have met three times in the postseason (1994, 2002, and 2021) with the Steelers winning the first two meetings, but losing the most recent in 2021.[\[110\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-111)[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-112)

#### Baltimore Ravens

Main article: [Ravens–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ravens%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Ravens–Steelers rivalry")

Pittsburgh's rivalry with the [Baltimore Ravens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens") has had several memorable matchups and has escalated into a fierce divisional rivalry. Both teams handed the other their first losses at their current home stadiums. The Steelers won the inaugural game played at [Baltimore's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore,_Maryland "Baltimore, Maryland") [M&T Bank Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%26T_Bank_Stadium "M&T Bank Stadium") in [1998](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_NFL_season "1998 NFL season"), 20–13, and three years later the [Ravens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens") handed the Steelers their first-ever loss at [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field"), 13–10. Later that season ( [2001](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_NFL_season "2001 NFL season")) Pittsburgh won a [divisional playoff game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001%E2%80%9302_NFL_playoffs#AFC:_Pittsburgh_Steelers_27,_Baltimore_Ravens_10 "2001–02 NFL playoffs") 27–10 against Baltimore, who was the [defending Super Bowl champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXV "Super Bowl XXXV"). During their NFL championship season in [2000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Baltimore_Ravens_season "2000 Baltimore Ravens season"), the Ravens defeated the Steelers [in Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium"), 16–0, in the season opener with the Steelers later exacting revenge, 9–6, in Baltimore (the Ravens' final loss of the season). During the Steelers 2008 Championship run, they beat the Ravens three times, including a win in the AFC Championship game. The two teams complement each other by consistently fielding strong defenses. The Steelers lead the all-time series (including playoffs), 32–24.[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-113) The teams have met four times in the postseason, with the Steelers owning a 3–1 record.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-j269-114)

#### Cincinnati Bengals

Main article: [Bengals–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengals%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Bengals–Steelers rivalry")

The Steelers' rivalry with the [Cincinnati Bengals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals "Cincinnati Bengals") dates from the [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1970 Pittsburgh Steelers season") season, when the [AFL–NFL merger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFL%E2%80%93NFL_merger "AFL–NFL merger") was completed. In [1976](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1976 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), the Steelers kept their playoff hopes alive (they later won the division) with a late-season 7–3 win in snowy Cincinnati. One of the most memorable games was the [2005 AFC Wildcard playoff game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_NFL_playoffs#AFC:_Pittsburgh_Steelers_31,_Cincinnati_Bengals_17 "2005–06 NFL playoffs"), in which the Steelers, en route to a [Super Bowl title](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XL "Super Bowl XL"), won a 31–17 come-from-behind victory after [Bengals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals "Cincinnati Bengals") quarterback [Carson Palmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Palmer "Carson Palmer") was forced to leave the game with a knee injury. The injury happened when nose tackle [Kimo von Oelhoffen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimo_von_Oelhoffen "Kimo von Oelhoffen") contacted Palmer's knee during a passing play.[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-115) The Bengals players called this a dirty play; the NFL ruled that it was accidental and did not fine von Oelhoffen for the hit. The incident led to an intensifying of the rivalry. The Bengals beat the Steelers in Week 13 of the [2005](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2005 Pittsburgh Steelers season") season 38–31, and wide receiver [T. J. Houshmandzadeh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._J._Houshmandzadeh "T. J. Houshmandzadeh") used a [Terrible Towel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrible_Towel "Terrible Towel") to polish his cleats while walking up the tunnel after the game, fueling the rivalry. The Steelers and Bengals finished [2005](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_NFL_season "2005 NFL season") and [2006](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_NFL_season "2006 NFL season") with identical records (11–5 and 8–8 respectively), splitting both regular-season series, the Bengals winning the tiebreaker both years due to having a superior division record. The Steelers also are responsible for ending the Bengals' season in Cincinnati two years in a row, eliminating them from the playoffs in [2005](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2005 Pittsburgh Steelers season") and taking them out of contention in [2006](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2006 Pittsburgh Steelers season"). The rivalry has become more intense again since the [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2015 Pittsburgh Steelers season") season. A central figure is Bengals linebacker [Vontaze Burfict](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vontaze_Burfict "Vontaze Burfict"), often inflicting brutal hits, resulting in serious injuries to several Steelers on multiple occasions. In the 2015 Wild Card playoff game in Cincinnati, Burfict was the culprit of a late penalty directly responsible for an extremely unlikely 18–16 Steelers comeback victory.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-ChrisBurke-61) The Steelers lead the all-time series, 63–35.[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-116) The teams have met twice in the postseason, with the Steelers winning both times.[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-117)

### Conference

#### New England Patriots

Main article: [Patriots–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriots%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Patriots–Steelers rivalry")

The [New England Patriots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") emerged as a prominent rival in league circles when the Patriots upset the Steelers in the 2001 [AFC Championship Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game") at [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field"), though the two teams had met in the postseason twice before; the Patriots defeated the Steelers in [1996](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_New_England_Patriots_season "1996 New England Patriots season") 28–3 while the Steelers won 7–6 in [1997](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1997 Pittsburgh Steelers season"); both times, the Patriots fielded players with Pittsburgh-area roots in [Ty Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ty_Law "Ty Law") and [Curtis Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtis_Martin "Curtis Martin"). Martin's final game with the Patriots was in the 1997 playoffs before he departed to the rival [New York Jets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_New_York_Jets_season "1998 New York Jets season"). Following the 2001 AFC title upset, the Patriots defeated the Steelers 30–14 at the start of the 2002 season. Pittsburgh did not exact revenge for the two losses until ending the Patriots' record-setting 21-game winning streak in week 6 of the [2004 NFL season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_NFL_season "2004 NFL season"). Later that season, the Steelers lost to the eventual Super Bowl champion Patriots in the AFC Championship game after a 15–1 regular season.

The Patriots won six of seven meetings over a ten-year period ( [1998](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_NFL_season "1998 NFL season")– [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_NFL_season "2007 NFL season")) before the Steelers broke through with a 33–10 victory at [Foxborough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gillette_Stadium "Gillette Stadium") in [2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_NFL_season "2008 NFL season"), after [Matt Cassel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Cassel "Matt Cassel") turned the ball over five times. The Patriots in [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2013 Pittsburgh Steelers season") then made history by becoming the first opponent to score 55 points on the Steelers, winning 55–31. The Patriots won again in 2015 (28–21) and 2016's regular season (27–16) and then won 36–17 in the 2016 [AFC Championship Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game"). They also won in 2017 when a go-ahead touchdown reception by Steelers' tight end [Jesse James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesse_James_(tight_end) "Jesse James (tight end)") was controversially called back.[\[117\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-118) Though they ultimately missed the playoffs, the Steelers defeated the Patriots by a score of 17–10 on December 16, 2018, in Pittsburgh.

In the postseason, the Patriots have outscored the Steelers 135–75, with the Patriots maintaining a 4–1 record. The only other franchises with winning AFC playoff records against Steelers include the [Los Angeles Chargers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Chargers "Los Angeles Chargers") (2–1), the [Jacksonville Jaguars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2007 Jacksonville Jaguars season") (2–0), and the Denver Broncos (5–3). The Steelers have an all-time regular-season record of 15–13 against the Patriots.[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-119) In the [Bill Belichick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Belichick "Bill Belichick") era, the main period of the rivalry, the Patriots have a 12–4 record against the Steelers. In their last matchup, the Patriots beat the Steelers 33–3 on [Sunday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Sunday_Night_Football "NBC Sunday Night Football").

#### Tennessee Titans

Main article: [Steelers–Titans rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steelers%E2%80%93Titans_rivalry "Steelers–Titans rivalry")

The Steelers have a rivalry with the [Tennessee Titans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans"), formerly the [Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston_Oilers "Houston Oilers")/Tennessee Oilers. The Oilers were aligned into the [AFC Central](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Central "AFC Central") with the Steelers in 1970 and were division rivals for 32 seasons. The Steelers dominated the rivalry during the Houston era and defeated the Oilers in all three of their playoff matchups. However, since the franchise moved to Tennessee in 1997, the rivalry shifted, with the Titans winning 13 of 22 meetings (including a bitter 34–31 playoff showdown in [2002](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2002 Pittsburgh Steelers season")); the Titans won seven in a row in the 1997–2001 period, the longest win streak by either team in the series. The Steelers have won 47 of 79 career meetings following their 27–24 win at [Nissan Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nissan_Stadium_(Nashville) "Nissan Stadium (Nashville)") in 2020.[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-120)

#### Denver Broncos

Main article: [Broncos–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broncos%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Broncos–Steelers rivalry")

The [Denver Broncos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") in 2011 broke a tie with the [Oakland Raiders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders") for the most playoff meetings versus the Steelers and added yet another meeting in 2015 (the Broncos have met Pittsburgh eight times to Oakland's six). The Steelers' rivalry with the Broncos dates from [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1970 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), but the first notable contest came in [1973](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1973_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1973 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), when Denver dealt Pittsburgh its first regular-season defeat at [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium"), 23–13. The following year, they met in the NFL's first regular-season overtime game, which ended in a 35–35 tie. Denver's first playoff game had them hosting the Steelers in the 1977 divisional round; the Broncos won 34–21. The following year, the Steelers hosted and defeated Denver 33–10 in the divisional round. Their next playoff matchup was the 1984 divisional round in [Mile High Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mile_High_Stadium "Mile High Stadium"); the Steelers pulled the upset 24–17. They nearly pulled the upset again 5 years later in Denver, but the Broncos prevailed in the divisional playoff, 24–23.

In 1997, the two teams met in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh") for the [AFC Championship Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game"), where Denver squeaked out at 24–21 win.[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-121) Eight years later, the Steelers advanced to [Super Bowl XL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XL "Super Bowl XL") by beating Denver 34–17 in Colorado. In 2011, after appearing in [Super Bowl XLV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV"), the Steelers had their campaign to repeat as [AFC Champions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football Conference") dashed in Denver after a stunning overtime upset by the [Tim Tebow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Tebow "Tim Tebow")-led Broncos in January 2012, in what would become known as the "316 game". The following September the Steelers were defeated in Denver 31–19 in [Peyton Manning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peyton_Manning "Peyton Manning")'s [debut as Broncos quarterback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Denver_Broncos_season "2012 Denver Broncos season"). The two clubs met twice in [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2015 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), as the Steelers defeated the Broncos in the regular season but fell in the Divisional Round of the AFC playoffs; through the 2021 season, Denver leads the series 20–13–1, including 5–3 in the playoffs.[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-122) Neither team has beaten the other more than three times in a row. In their last matchup, the Steelers beat the Broncos on October 10, 2021, in Pittsburgh by the score of 27–19.

#### Oakland/Los Angeles/Las Vegas Raiders

Main article: [Raiders–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raiders%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Raiders–Steelers rivalry")

The Steelers' rivalry with the Raiders was one of the most heated battles of the 1970s and early to mid-1980s. The Steelers' first playoff victory in franchise history came against the Raiders, which occurred on December 23, 1972, in a 13–7 victory over the Raiders; the victory occurred when [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw") threw a pass intended for [John Fuqua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Fuqua "John Fuqua") that was deflected into the hands of [Franco Harris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Harris "Franco Harris"), who scooped the ball from nearly hitting the ground and carried the ball in for a touchdown, which was later referred to as the [Immaculate Reception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immaculate_Reception "Immaculate Reception"), while attracting controversy from Raiders players and coaches, who alleged that the ball had bounced off Fuqua, which would have made it an illegal play per the rules of the time.[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-123) The victory sent Pittsburgh to their first-ever AFC Championship Game. The following year, the two teams met in the Divisional Round again, and the Raiders responded with a 33–14 victory to advance to the AFC title game. However, Pittsburgh fired back with two straight AFC Championship victories over the Raiders in [1974](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1974_NFL_season "1974 NFL season") (24–13) and [1975](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1975_NFL_season "1975 NFL season") (16–10) to reach the [Super Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"). The Raiders responded with a victory over Pittsburgh in the [1976](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_NFL_season "1976 NFL season") AFC Championship game 24–7 (the third consecutive AFC title game between the two teams), but not before [Chuck Noll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Noll "Chuck Noll") referred to Raider [George Atkinson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Atkinson_(safety) "George Atkinson (safety)") as part of the NFL's "criminal element" after his alleged cheap-shot on [Lynn Swann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynn_Swann "Lynn Swann") during a regular-season matchup. Atkinson and the Raiders later filed a [defamation of character](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamation_of_character "Defamation of character") [lawsuit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawsuit "Lawsuit") against Noll, but lost. Following the 1983 regular season, the Los Angeles Raiders defeated the Steelers 38–10 in the AFC Divisional round, which turned out to be the last NFL game for Steeler Pro Football Hall of Fame quarterback [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw"), who did not play due to injury.

While the rivalry has dissipated over the years (mostly due to the Raiders decline after [2002](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Oakland_Raiders_season "2002 Oakland Raiders season")), the teams have had notable games against each other, including an upset Steelers victory towards the end of the [2000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2000 Pittsburgh Steelers season") season to prevent the Raiders from obtaining homefield advantage in the playoffs, and an upset Raiders victory in week 8 of the [2006 NFL season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_NFL_season "2006 NFL season") (20–13), which helped cost the Steelers a playoff berth. In Week 13 of the 2009 season, another Raiders upset victory happened; the game lead changed five times on five touchdowns in the fourth quarter until Raiders QB [Bruce Gradkowski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Gradkowski "Bruce Gradkowski")'s third touchdown of the quarter won it with nine seconds to go. The 27–24 loss cost the Steelers another playoff run. The teams met at [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field") in [2010](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2010 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), where the Steelers blew out the Raiders 35–3, and ended their 3-game winning streak; the game was further notable for a punch thrown by [Richard Seymour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Seymour "Richard Seymour") of the Raiders against Steelers quarterback [Ben Roethlisberger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Roethlisberger "Ben Roethlisberger"). The Raiders then hosted the Steelers in [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Oakland_Raiders_season "2012 Oakland Raiders season") and erased a 31–21 gap to win 34–31. The two clubs met again in [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_NFL_season "2013 NFL season") and the Raiders won again, 21–18. In 2015, the Steelers defeated the Raiders 38–35 at Heinz Field.

On December 9, 2018, in Oakland, the Raiders defeated the Steelers 24–21, which, ironically, would cost Pittsburgh another playoff berth.[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-124) The Raiders won at Pittsburgh on September 19, 2021, 26–17, then fell on [Christmas Eve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_Eve "Christmas Eve") 2022 at Pittsburgh 13–10 on a last-minute touchdown by rookie Steelers quarterback [Kenny Pickett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenny_Pickett "Kenny Pickett"). A lifeless performance in a 23–18 loss at Vegas on September 23, 2023, contributed to the later firing of Raiders coach [Josh McDaniels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_McDaniels "Josh McDaniels") and GM [Dave Ziegler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Ziegler "Dave Ziegler"). As of the 2024 season, the Raiders lead the all-time series 17–16.[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-125)

### Interconference

#### Dallas Cowboys

Main article: [Cowboys–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cowboys%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Cowboys–Steelers rivalry")

The Steelers once took part in a historic rivalry with the [Dallas Cowboys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys")[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-126) started with the Cowboys' first game as a franchise in [1960](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_NFL_season "1960 NFL season") (against the Steelers) at the [Cotton Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_Bowl_(stadium) "Cotton Bowl (stadium)") with the Steelers coming away with a 35–28 victory. These teams hold a record for the most times (three) that two teams have met in a [Super Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"). The first two times the favored Steelers and Cowboys met came with Pittsburgh victories in the Orange Bowl [Super Bowl X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_X "Super Bowl X") 21–17 and [Super Bowl XIII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XIII "Super Bowl XIII") 35–31. The Cowboys never won a regular-season game in the Orange Bowl and lost three Super Bowl games (once to the Baltimore Colts and twice to the Steelers). Between the Cowboys and Steelers, Super Bowl XIII had the greatest number of future Pro Football Hall of Fame players participating, which as of 2021 numbered 25 – 16 players and nine coaches/front office, including [Ernie Stautner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernie_Stautner "Ernie Stautner"), [defensive coordinator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_coordinator "Defensive coordinator") for the Cowboys who was a HoF [defensive tackle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_tackle "Defensive tackle") for the Steelers. The teams featured an all-star matchup at quarterback between the Steelers' [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw") and the Cowboys' [Roger Staubach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Staubach "Roger Staubach"), both of whom are in the [Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame"). In [1977](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1977_NFL_season "1977 NFL season"), Staubach and the Cowboys won [Super Bowl XII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XII "Super Bowl XII"), their second and last loss of their season being inflicted by Bradshaw and the Steelers, 28–13 at Three Rivers Stadium in November. In [1979](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_NFL_season "1979 NFL season"), Staubach's final season, the two defending conference champs met again at Three Rivers, the Steelers winning 14–3 en route to winning their [fourth Super Bowl title](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XIV "Super Bowl XIV"). The Steelers won six of eight meetings during the 1970s and 80s, before the Cowboys won all four meetings during the 1990s, including the teams' record third Super Bowl meeting in [1996](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXX "Super Bowl XXX"), as this time the heavily favored Cowboys beat the Steelers 27–17. Dallas cornerback [Larry Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Brown_(cornerback) "Larry Brown (cornerback)") intercepted Pittsburgh quarterback [Neil O'Donnell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_O%27Donnell "Neil O'Donnell") twice and was named the game's MVP. The teams' first two meetings of the 21st century ( [2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_NFL_season "2004 NFL season") and [2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_NFL_season "2008 NFL season")) were won by the Steelers, including a come from behind victory on December 7, 2008, in Pittsburgh, when the Steelers drove the length of the field to tie the game 13–13, then [cornerback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornerback "Cornerback") [Deshea Townsend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deshea_Townsend "Deshea Townsend") returned an intercepted pass from [Tony Romo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Romo "Tony Romo") for the game's final score, Steelers 20, Cowboys 13. The Cowboys won on December 16, 2012, at Cowboys Stadium by a 27–24 margin in overtime and won 35–30 at [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field") on November 13, 2016. The all-time series is led by the Dallas Cowboys, 17–16.[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-127) The Pittsburgh/Dallas rivalry served as a backdrop to the 1977 film _[Black Sunday](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Sunday_(1977_film) "Black Sunday (1977 film)")_, parts of which were filmed during Super Bowl X. Most recently, the Steelers beat the Cowboys by a 24–19 margin.

#### Philadelphia Eagles

Main article: [Eagles–Steelers rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Eagles–Steelers rivalry")

The [Philadelphia Eagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") and Steelers are both located in [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania") and began play in 1933. From that season through 1966, this was a major rivalry for both teams, as both were part of the same division. In 1967, they were placed in separate divisions, but remained in the same conference for three years. In 1970 the Steelers (along with the [Cleveland Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") and [Baltimore Colts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_Colts "Baltimore Colts")) moved to the [American Football Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football Conference"), while the Eagles stayed with the rest of the old-line NFL teams in the [National Football Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_Conference "National Football Conference"). As a result, the Eagles and Steelers no longer played each other every year; instead, they are scheduled to meet once every four years in the regular season. The most recent meeting was in 2024 at Lincoln Financial Field, a game in which the Eagles won 27–13. The Steelers have lost 11 straight games on the road against the Eagles dating back to 1966, which was also the start of the [Super Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") era. The Eagles lead the all-time series 50–29–3.[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-128)

## Culture

### Mascot

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/SteelyMcBeam.jpg/250px-SteelyMcBeam.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:SteelyMcBeam.jpg) Steely McBeam signing autographs for fans at Steelers training camp on August 2, 2007

Prior to the [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2007 Pittsburgh Steelers season") season, the Steelers introduced Steely McBeam as their official mascot.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CatchingUp-129) As part of the 75th anniversary celebrations of the team, his name was selected from a pool of 70,000 suggestions submitted by fans of the team.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CatchingUp-129) Diane Roles of [Middlesex Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middlesex_Township,_Butler_County,_Pennsylvania "Middlesex Township, Butler County, Pennsylvania"), submitted the winning name which was "meant to represent steel for Pittsburgh's industrial heritage, "Mc" for the Rooney family's Irish roots, and Beam for the steel beams produced in Pittsburgh, as well as for [Jim Beam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Beam "Jim Beam"), her husband's favorite alcoholic beverage."[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-Name-130) Steely McBeam is visible at all home games and participates in the team's charitable programs and other club-sponsored events.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CatchingUp-129) Steely's autograph is known to be drawn with an oversized _S_, and the _L_ is drawn to look like a beam of steel.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CatchingUp-129)

### Fanbase

Main article: [Steeler Nation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steeler_Nation "Steeler Nation")

The Steelers have a tradition of having a large fanbase, which has spread from Pittsburgh. In August 2008, [ESPN.com](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN.com "ESPN.com") ranked the Steelers' fans as the best in the NFL, citing their "unbelievable" sellout streak of 299 consecutive games.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-Mosley-12)[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-131) The team gained a large fan base nationally based on its success in the 1970s, but many consider the collapse of the city's steel industry at the end of the 1970s dynasty into the 1980s (and the resulting [diaspora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaspora "Diaspora")) to be a large catalyst for the size of the fan base in other cities.[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-132) The Steelers have sold out every home game since the [1972](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1972_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1972 Pittsburgh Steelers season") season.[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CopeDeath-133)

The Pittsburgh Steelers have numerous unofficial fan clubs in many cities throughout the country, that typically meet in bars or taverns on game days. This phenomenon is known to occur for other NFL teams as well, but "Steeler bars" are more visible than most, including representative establishments even in cities that field their own NFL teams.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/US_Navy_090202-N-5253W-043_Sailors_and_Marines_aboard_the_amphibious_assault_ship_USS_Essex_%28LHD_2%29_react_as_the_Pittsburgh_Steelers_score_against_the_Arizona_Cardinals_late_in_the_fourth_quarter_of_Superbowl_XLIII.jpg/250px-thumbnail.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:US_Navy_090202-N-5253W-043_Sailors_and_Marines_aboard_the_amphibious_assault_ship_USS_Essex_(LHD_2)_react_as_the_Pittsburgh_Steelers_score_against_the_Arizona_Cardinals_late_in_the_fourth_quarter_of_Superbowl_XLIII.jpg) Sailors and Marines aboard the USS _Essex_ react as the Pittsburgh Steelers score against the Arizona Cardinals.

The [Terrible Towel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrible_Towel "Terrible Towel") has been described by the Associated Press as "arguably the best-known [fan symbol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rally_towel "Rally towel") of any major pro sports team".[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CopeDeath-133) Conceived of by broadcaster [Myron Cope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myron_Cope "Myron Cope") in [1975](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1975_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1975 Pittsburgh Steelers season"),[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-CopeDeath-133) the towel's rights have since been given to the [Allegheny Valley School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_Valley_School "Allegheny Valley School") in [Coraopolis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coraopolis,_Pennsylvania "Coraopolis, Pennsylvania"), which cares for over 900 people with [intellectual disability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intellectual_disability "Intellectual disability") and [physical disabilities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disability "Disability"), including Cope's [autistic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autism "Autism") son.[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-AVSchool-134) Since 1996, proceeds from the Terrible Towel have helped raise more than $2.5 million for the school.[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-AVSchool-134)

### Fight songs

The Steelers have no official fight song, but many fan versions of "Steelers Polka" (a parody of " [Pennsylvania Polka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_Polka "Pennsylvania Polka")") by ethnic singer Jimmy Pol, both originating in the 1970s, have been recorded. Since 1994, the song " [Here We Go](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Here_We_Go_(Steelers_song) "Here We Go (Steelers song)")" by local singer Roger Wood has been popular among fans.[\[134\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-135) Since 2002, the 1979 [Styx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styx_(band) "Styx (band)") song " [Renegade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renegade_(Styx_song) "Renegade (Styx song)")" is played near the end of the third quarter or the start of the fourth quarter at the start of a defensive stand to rally the crowd, featuring a compilation of recent Steelers defensive highlights. Another song from hometown rapper [Wiz Khalifa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiz_Khalifa "Wiz Khalifa"), " [Black and Yellow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_and_Yellow "Black and Yellow")", which is an ode to growing up in Pittsburgh, is also a standard part of the Steelers home game experience.[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-136)

### Cheerleaders

Main article: [Pittsburgh Steelerettes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelerettes "Pittsburgh Steelerettes")

The Steelers were the first NFL team to have a [cheerleading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheerleading "Cheerleading") squad, they were known as the Steelerettes. Their run only lasted from 1961 to 1969. To this day, they were the only cheerleaders the team had in their history.[\[136\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-137)

### Basketball

During the offseason, the Steelers have long participated in charity [basketball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") games throughout [Western Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Pennsylvania "Western Pennsylvania") and neighboring areas. The games usually feature six active players as well as their [player-coach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Player-coach "Player-coach") playing against a group of local civic leaders.[\[137\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-138) The players, whose participants aren't announced until the day of the game, sign free autographs for fans during halftime.[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-139)

## Facilities

### Stadiums

In 2001, the Steelers moved into [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field").[\[139\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-a384-140) The franchise dating back to 1933 has had several homes.[\[140\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-141) For 31 seasons, the Steelers shared [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field") with the [Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates "Pittsburgh Pirates") from 1933 to 1963. In 1958, though they started splitting their home games at [Pitt Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitt_Stadium "Pitt Stadium") three blocks away at the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"). From 1964 to 1969, the Steelers played exclusively at the on-campus facility before moving with the Pirates to [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") on the city's [Northside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northside_(Pittsburgh) "Northside (Pittsburgh)"). The team moved to what was then known as Heinz Field in 2001. In February 2022, after Heinz declined to sign a new deal after naming rights expired, the Steelers signed a deal with [Acrisure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acrisure "Acrisure") and renamed the stadium to Acrisure Stadium.[\[141\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-a712-142)

### Training camp

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Steelerstrainingcamp.jpg/250px-Steelerstrainingcamp.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Steelerstrainingcamp.jpg) Steelers at training camp in Latrobe

The Steelers hold [training camp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Training_camp_(National_Football_League) "Training camp (National Football League)") east of the city at [Saint Vincent College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Vincent_College "Saint Vincent College") in [Latrobe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latrobe,_Pennsylvania "Latrobe, Pennsylvania").[\[142\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-c461-143) The site is one of the most storied in the league with [Peter King](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_King_(sportswriter) "Peter King (sportswriter)") of SI.com describing it as: "... I love the place. It's the perfect training-camp setting, looking out over the rolling hills of the [Laurel Highlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurel_Highlands "Laurel Highlands") in [west-central Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Pennsylvania "Western Pennsylvania"), an hour east of Pittsburgh. On a misty or foggy morning, standing atop the hill at the college, you feel like you're in [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"). Classic, wonderful slice of [American culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_culture "American culture"). If you can visit one training camp, this is the one to see."[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-144)

The team has its headquarters and practice facilities at the state-of-the-art [University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Sportsplex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UPMC_Sports_Performance_Complex "UPMC Sports Performance Complex") on Pittsburgh's [Southside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southside_(Pittsburgh) "Southside (Pittsburgh)"). Constructed in 2000, the facility combines the vast expertise of sports medical professionals and researchers as well as hosting the [University of Pittsburgh Panthers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_Panthers "University of Pittsburgh Panthers") football team.[\[144\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-145)

In 2020 and 2021, due to the [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") pandemic, the Steelers held their training camp at Heinz Field. They returned to Saint Vincent College for the 2022 season.[\[145\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-f356-146)

### Historical facilities

The Rooney family has long had a close relationship with [Duquesne University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duquesne_University "Duquesne University") in the city and from the teams founding in the 1930s to the late 1990s used [Art Rooney Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_J._Rooney_Athletic_Field "Arthur J. Rooney Athletic Field") and other facilities on campus as either its primary or secondary in-season training site as well as [Greenlee Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenlee_Field "Greenlee Field") during the 1930s.[\[146\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-147)

In the 1970s and 1980s, the team had season scrimmages at [South Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Park_Township "South Park Township") in the [suburban south hills](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_metropolitan_area "Pittsburgh metropolitan area") of Pittsburgh. During various seasons including the [strike season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987_NFL_season "1987 NFL season") of 1987, the Steelers used [Point Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_Stadium "Point Stadium") in nearby [Johnstown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnstown,_Pennsylvania "Johnstown, Pennsylvania") for game week practices.[\[147\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-148) During the 1950s [St. Bonaventure University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Bonaventure_University "St. Bonaventure University") (where Art Rooney's brother Silas was serving as athletic director)[\[148\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-DEB-149)[\[149\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-150) and suburban [Ligonier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ligonier,_Pennsylvania "Ligonier, Pennsylvania")[\[150\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-151) also served as a pre-season training camp sites.

### Retired uniform numbers

| Pittsburgh Steelers retired numbers |

The Steelers retired Stautner's #70 in 1964 before creating a 50-year tradition of not retiring numbers. The team retired Greene's #75 in 2014 and left the possibility open that they would retire other players' jersey numbers at later dates. However, several numbers have not been reissued since the retirement of the players who wore them, including:[\[154\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-155)

- **1** [Gary Anderson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Anderson_(placekicker) "Gary Anderson (placekicker)")
- **7** [Ben Roethlisberger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Roethlisberger "Ben Roethlisberger")
- **12** [Terry Bradshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw "Terry Bradshaw")
- **36** [Jerome Bettis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerome_Bettis "Jerome Bettis")
- **43** [Troy Polamalu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy_Polamalu "Troy Polamalu")
- **47** [Mel Blount](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_Blount "Mel Blount")
- **52** [Mike Webster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Webster "Mike Webster")
- **58** [Jack Lambert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Lambert_(American_football) "Jack Lambert (American football)")
- **59** [Jack Ham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Ham "Jack Ham")
- **63** [Dermontti Dawson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dermontti_Dawson "Dermontti Dawson")
- **86** [Hines Ward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hines_Ward "Hines Ward")

Numbers 1 (by [Anthony Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Wright_(American_football) "Anthony Wright (American football)")), 47 (by several players), and 59 (by [Todd Seabaugh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_Seabaugh "Todd Seabaugh")) were regularly issued for a time before being taken out of circulation. Number 31 was initially taken out of circulation in honor of [Donnie Shell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donnie_Shell "Donnie Shell"), but was reissued with Shell's blessing in 2001 to [Mike Logan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Logan_(American_football) "Mike Logan (American football)"), who grew up in suburban [McKeesport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McKeesport,_Pennsylvania "McKeesport, Pennsylvania") and had idolized Shell when he was younger.[\[155\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-156) After Logan retired in 2006, 31 returned to regular circulation, likely due to 36 being removed for Bettis as well as 47 being removed due to some controversy involving the number being issued multiple times following Blount's retirement. Notably, numbers 80 ( [Jack Butler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Butler_(American_football) "Jack Butler (American football)")), 82 ( [John Stallworth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Stallworth "John Stallworth")), 83 ( [Louis Lipps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Lipps "Louis Lipps") & [Heath Miller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heath_Miller "Heath Miller")), 84 ( [Antonio Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Brown "Antonio Brown")), and 88 ( [Lynn Swann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynn_Swann "Lynn Swann")) remain in circulation despite the NFL [relaxing uniform numbering rules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_uniform_numbers "NFL uniform numbers") and more numbers being available for receivers.

### Pro Football Hall of Famers

#### "Primary" inductees

The Steelers boast the third most "primary" [inductees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame_inductees "List of Pro Football Hall of Fame inductees") into the [Pro Football Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame"), i.e. inductees that spent most or all of their NFL careers in Pittsburgh. They also can claim the most honorees of any franchise founded on or after [1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1933_NFL_season "1933 NFL season") and the only franchise with three members of ownership in the Hall of Fame.[\[156\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-profootballhof1-157)

### NFL All-Decade Teams

The following Steelers were named to NFL All-Decade Teams (and 75th and 100th Anniversary All-Time Teams, selected in 1994 and 2019, respectively). Only those who spent time with Pittsburgh during the respective decades are listed.
**Bold** indicates those elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

### All-time team

In [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2007 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), in celebration of the franchise's 75th season, the team announced an updated [All-Time team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers_All-Time_Team "Pittsburgh Steelers All-Time Team") of the 33 best players who have ever played for the Steelers.[\[199\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-PressRelease-200) This team supplanted the [previous All-Time team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers_All-Time_Team_(50th_Season) "Pittsburgh Steelers All-Time Team (50th Season)") of 24 players named as part of the 50th anniversary commemoration in [1982](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1982_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1982 Pittsburgh Steelers season").[\[200\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-201)

A ["Legends team"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers_Legends_team "Pittsburgh Steelers Legends team") consisting of the club's best pre-1970s players was released concurrently with the latest All-Time team.[\[201\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-LegendsPressRelease-202)

Further information: [Pittsburgh Steelers All-Time Team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers_All-Time_Team "Pittsburgh Steelers All-Time Team")

## Coaches

Main article: [List of Pittsburgh Steelers head coaches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_Steelers_head_coaches "List of Pittsburgh Steelers head coaches")

The Steelers have had 16 coaches through their history.[\[217\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-218) They have cycled through the fewest [head coaches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_coach "Head coach") in the modern NFL history.[\[218\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-219) Their first coach was [Forrest Douds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forrest_Douds "Forrest Douds"), who coached them to a 3–6–2 record in [1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1933_Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NFL)_season "1933 Pittsburgh Pirates (NFL) season"). [Chuck Noll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Noll "Chuck Noll") had the longest term as head coach with the Steelers; he is one of only four coaches to coach a single NFL team for 23 years.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7) Hired prior to the [2007 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2007 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), the Steelers current coach is [Mike Tomlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Tomlin "Mike Tomlin").[\[219\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-220)

## Media

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Pittsburgh_Steelers_radio_affiliates.png/250px-Pittsburgh_Steelers_radio_affiliates.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Steelers_radio_affiliates.png) Map of radio affiliates.

Further information: [Pittsburgh Steelers Radio Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers_Radio_Network "Pittsburgh Steelers Radio Network")

As of 2006, the Steelers' [flagship radio stations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flagship_(radio) "Flagship (radio)") were [WDVE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDVE "WDVE") 102.5 FM and [WBGG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBGG_(AM) "WBGG (AM)") 970 AM. Both stations are owned by [iHeartMedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IHeartMedia "IHeartMedia"). Games are also available on 51 radio stations in [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"), [Western Maryland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Maryland "Western Maryland"), [Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio "Ohio"), and Northern [West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia").[\[221\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-222) The announcer is [Tunch Ilkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tunch_Ilkin "Tunch Ilkin"). [Craig Wolfley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craig_Wolfley "Craig Wolfley") is the sideline reporter. [Myron Cope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myron_Cope "Myron Cope"), the longtime [color analyst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_analyst "Color analyst") and inventor of the " [Terrible Towel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrible_Towel "Terrible Towel")", retired after the [2004 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_NFL_season "2004 NFL season"), and died in 2008. Longtime lead announcer [Bill Hillgrove](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Hillgrove "Bill Hillgrove") retired after the [2023 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_NFL_season "2023 NFL season").

Pre-season games not shown on one of the national broadcasters are seen on [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS "CBS") [O&O](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Owned-and-operated_station "Owned-and-operated station") [KDKA-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDKA-TV "KDKA-TV"), channel 2; independent sister station [WPKD-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPKD-TV "WPKD-TV"), channel 19; and [AT&T SportsNet Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Pittsburgh "AT&T SportsNet Pittsburgh"). KDKA-TV's [Bob Pompeani](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bob_Pompeani&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bob Pompeani (page does not exist)") and former Steelers quarterback [Charlie Batch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Batch "Charlie Batch") do the announcing for the pre-season games, as well as the two hosting the pre-game program _Steelers Kickoff_ during the regular season prior to the national airing of _[The NFL Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_NFL_Today "The NFL Today")_. Pompeani and former Steelers [lineman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lineman_(American_football) "Lineman (American football)") [Chris Hoke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Hoke "Chris Hoke") also host the _Xfinity Xtra Point_ following the game on days when [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS "CBS") does not have that week's NFL doubleheader. When CBS has a week's doubleheader, the show airs on WPKD-TV. Coach Mike Tomlin's weekly press conference is shown live on AT&T SportsNet Pittsburgh. Both Batch and Hoke replaced former Steelers lineman [Edmund Nelson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Nelson_(American_football) "Edmund Nelson (American football)"), who retired from broadcasting in 2015.[\[222\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-223)

_[Thursday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thursday_Night_Football "Thursday Night Football")_ broadcasts are shown locally on [Fox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") affiliate [WPGH-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPGH-TV "WPGH-TV"), channel 53 (along with home games with NFC opponents and some flexed interconference games), while _[ESPN Monday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN_Monday_Night_Football "ESPN Monday Night Football")_ broadcasts are shown locally on [WTAE-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WTAE-TV "WTAE-TV"), channel 4. (WTAE-TV is owned by the [Hearst Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearst_Corporation "Hearst Corporation"), which owns a 20% stake in ESPN.) By virtue of being members of the AFC, most of the Steelers' games air on CBS and KDKA. _[NBC Sunday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Sunday_Night_Football "NBC Sunday Night Football")_ games are carried by [WPXI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPXI "WPXI"), channel 11, in the market.

The Steelers hold a national contract with [Grupo Imagen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grupo_Imagen "Grupo Imagen") for radio rights to their games in Mexico; Imagen broadcasts the Steelers on their stations in 17 Mexican cities.

### Figures with broadcasting résumés

Main article: [List of Pittsburgh Steelers figures in broadcasting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_Steelers_figures_in_broadcasting "List of Pittsburgh Steelers figures in broadcasting")

The Steelers franchise has a rich history of producing well-known sportscasters over the years. The most famous of these is probably [Myron Cope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myron_Cope "Myron Cope"), who served as a Steelers radio [color commentator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_commentator "Color commentator") for 35 seasons ( [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1970 Pittsburgh Steelers season")– [2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2004 Pittsburgh Steelers season")).[\[223\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-n230-224)

Several former Steelers players have gone on to careers in media after completing their playing careers.

### Newspaper

The _Steelers Digest_ is the only official newspaper for the Pittsburgh Steelers.[\[224\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-i972-225) It has been published for 22 years and is currently published by Dolphin/Curtis Publishing in Miami, Florida, which also handles several other publications. The newspaper is very widely acknowledged by Steelers fans. Issues are mailed out to paying subscribers weekly through the season after every regular-season game and continue through playoffs as long as the Steelers do. After a Super Bowl victory, a bonus issue is published, which is followed by a draft preview, draft recap, and training camp edition every other month, then leading into the pre-season. There are typically 24 issues of the paper within a publishing year. The newspaper is listed on the official Steelers.com page.

## The Chuck Noll Foundation for Brain Injury Research

The Steelers helped launch the Chuck Noll Foundation for Brain Injury Research in November 2016 by donating $1 million.[\[239\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-240) The Foundation, started by Steelers president Art Rooney II, focuses on education and research regarding brain injuries and sports-related concussions.[\[240\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-z857-241)

In June 2017, the Steelers announced an inaugural charity walk to raise money for the foundation.[\[241\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-242)

## Notes

1. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_ref-100 "Jump up")**Although [Marlin Briscoe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marlin_Briscoe "Marlin Briscoe") is sometimes erroneously cited as the first African-American starting quarterback in 1968, this was not for an NFL team and not in an NFL game (the Denver Broncos, for which Briscoe played, were an American Football League team then), additionally the vast majority of Briscoe's career was not as quarterback.
